description: Distribution refers to the way data is spread out or clustered over a range of values. It helps to understand the overall pattern in a dataset and identifies how frequently values occur.

common_types.name: Normal Distribution
common_types.description: Also known as Gaussian distribution, it is a symmetric, bell-shaped distribution where most of the data points cluster around the mean.

common_types.name: Uniform Distribution
common_types.description: In a uniform distribution, all outcomes are equally likely. The probability is constant across the range of possible values.

common_types.name: Skewed Distribution
common_types.description: A distribution that is not symmetrical. It can be left-skewed (negatively skewed) or right-skewed (positively skewed), depending on the direction of the tail.

common_types.name: Bimodal Distribution
common_types.description: Characterized by having two distinct peaks. This occurs when the data contains two different modes.

visualization_techniques.description: A graphical representation of the distribution of numerical data, using bars to show the frequency of data intervals.
Displays the data distribution based on a five-number summary (minimum, first quartile, median, third quartile, and maximum), highlighting outliers.
A smoothed version of a histogram, used to estimate the probability density function of a continuous variable.
Combines aspects of a box plot and a density plot to show the distribution shape along with statistical summaries.

applications: Understanding data spread before applying statistical analysis.
Detecting outliers or unusual patterns in the data.
Choosing appropriate statistical models based on data distribution.
